purpose: The email announces a special issue on Emerging Concerns in Technical Debt Management for publication in the Empirical Software Engineering (EMSE) journal. It invites contributions that explore how emerging concerns in AI, data-intensive systems, and other evolving domains impact the understanding and management of technical debt. The email outlines the scope of the special issue, highlighting new implications for technical debt research, including data quality, ethical considerations, and scalability challenges. It encourages submissions that provide empirical studies, evidence-based analyses, or innovative methodologies related to technical debt in these contexts. The email also specifies important dates and provides contact information for guest editors.

evidence_sentences: We are pleased to announce a special issue focusing on Emerging Concerns in Technical Debt Management for publication in Empirical Software Engineering (EMSE).
This special issue invites contributions investigating how emerging concerns in AI, data-intensive systems, and other evolving domains affect our understanding and management of TD.
These emerging concerns often introduce new implications for Technical Debt research and practice, including: Data Quality and Evolution, Ethical and Fairness Considerations, Scalability Challenges.
We encourage submissions that clearly motivate and justify the 'novelty' of the systems or concerns being studied, particularly in relation to existing TD literature.
Topics of Interest: We seek submissions that address the following topics or related areas: Manifestations of TD in data-driven, AI-enabled, cyber-physical, or distributed systems.
Submissions must clearly articulate how the chosen domain or system introduces unique considerations or challenges for TD research and practice.
